metadata.name: Global Fire Ecology Reasoning Framework
metadata.description: Fire-adapted ecosystem knowledge for any geographic location - prevents hallucination by encoding reasoning logic, not location-specific facts
metadata.philosophy: This KB encodes HOW to reason about fire ecology, not WHAT species exist in specific regions

fire_regime_classification.description: Global fire regime types - applicable to any location

surface_fire_regime.description: Low-intensity fires that burn along forest floor
surface_fire_regime.ecological_role: Maintains open structure, cycles nutrients, reduces fuel
surface_fire_regime.suppression_effects: Fuel buildup leads to more severe fires

crown_fire_regime.description: High-intensity fires that reach tree canopy
crown_fire_regime.ecological_role: Stand replacement, mosaic creation, successional reset
crown_fire_regime.suppression_effects: Larger, more uniform patches when fires occur

shrubland_fire_regime.ecological_role: Triggers seed germination, maintains shrub dominance
shrubland_fire_regime.suppression_effects: Type conversion if fire excluded too long

grassland_fire_regime.description: Frequent, fast-moving fires in grass-dominated systems

peatland_fire_regime.ecological_role: NONE - peatland fires are disturbance outside natural regime

physical_changes: Soil heating kills mycorrhizal fungi to 5-10cm depth
biological_responses: Wildlife may temporarily flee but return quickly

physical_changes: Soil stability improves with vegetation cover
biological_responses: Shrub canopy closure in shrubland systems
Pioneer trees establish if seed source present

shrubland_systems: Senescence and increased fire risk as fuel accumulates

vegetation_response_types.description: How plants respond to fire - applicable globally

resprouters.definition: Survive fire and regrow from protected buds
resprouters.restoration_implication: Often do NOT need replanting - check for resprouts first
resprouters.global_examples: Eucalyptus (Australia), Quercus (Mediterranean, California), many tropical trees

obligate_seeders.definition: Adults killed by fire, regenerate from seed
obligate_seeders.restoration_implication: May need seeding if seed bank depleted or no seed source
obligate_seeders.global_examples: Many Pinus spp., Banksia (Australia), many annual forbs

fire_stimulated_germinants.definition: Seeds require fire cues (heat, smoke) to germinate
fire_stimulated_germinants.restoration_implication: Natural regeneration often excellent - wait before planting
fire_stimulated_germinants.global_examples: Ceanothus, many Fabaceae, many fynbos species

fire_sensitive.definition: Killed by fire, no fire-adaptive traits
fire_sensitive.restoration_implication: May require active planting if seed source distant
fire_sensitive.global_examples: Many rainforest species, some high-elevation conifers

biome_fire_ecology.description: Fire ecology by major biome type - use when region is unknown

mediterranean_ecosystems.professional_caution: Post-fire invasive grass invasion is major concern

temperate_conifer_forest.recovery_notes: Depends on severity; high severity may need intervention

boreal_forest.recovery_notes: Stand replacement is natural; mosaic pattern important
boreal_forest.professional_caution: Climate change increasing fire frequency beyond adaptation

tropical_savanna.recovery_notes: Very fast grass recovery, tree recovery slower
tropical_savanna.professional_caution: Fire is necessary - suppression causes woody encroachment

eucalyptus_forest.professional_caution: Extremely high fuel loads and fire intensity

tropical_rainforest.recovery_notes: Very slow recovery; may not recover to rainforest
tropical_rainforest.professional_caution: Fire indicates ecosystem degradation, not natural process

active_vs_passive_restoration_logic.description: Decision framework for when to intervene

conditions_favoring_natural_recovery: Resprouting species present and showing vigor
Not at risk of type conversion
passive_restoration_indicators.professional_recommendation: Wait 1-3 years before deciding on active intervention

conditions_requiring_intervention: Burn severity > 70% with no nearby seed source
High erosion risk requiring rapid cover
Type conversion imminent (forest → shrubland, native → invasive)
Fire regime historically infrequent (vegetation not adapted)
Little resprouting observed after 1 growing season
active_restoration_indicators.professional_caution: Intervention can be counterproductive if done too early

uncertainty_and_data_gaps.description: How to handle regions without specific knowledge

when_region_unknown.approach: Use biome-level reasoning, not species-specific claims
permitted_statements: Based on the [biome type], typical recovery patterns include...
Fire-adapted ecosystems in this climate zone generally...
Without region-specific data, general principles suggest...
prohibited_statements: This species should be planted... (without regional data)
The following native species occur here... (speculation)
Recovery will take X years... (false precision)
must_disclose: Regional species data not available in knowledge base
Recommend consultation with local ecological expertise
General biome-level assessment only - site-specific verification needed

confidence_calibration.action: Calibrate language uncertainty to match regional data quality

professional_judgment_rules.description: Rules that prevent hallucination and enforce professional standards
core_principles: Absence of evidence is NOT evidence of anything
Biome-level reasoning when region-specific data unavailable
prohibited_behaviors: Recommending specific species without regional data
Claiming precise recovery timelines without site data
Applying California species knowledge to other regions
Treating fire as inherently destructive (it is often beneficial)
Ignoring that some ecosystems are NOT fire-adapted
required_behaviors: Check if region has specific data before making claims
Use biome-level reasoning for unknown regions
Explicitly state when data is limited
Recommend local expert consultation for unknown regions
